title: Identifying Red Flags in Text Scams
description: Learn to spot the warning signs that indicate a text message might be a scam, regardless of the specific scenario.

sections.title: Introduction to Red Flags
sections.body: While scam messages come in many forms, they often share common characteristics or 'red flags' that can help you identify them. By learning to recognize these warning signs, you can protect yourself from most scams, even those using new or unfamiliar scenarios. This module will teach you the key indicators that should make you suspicious of any message you receive.

sections.title: Urgency and Time Pressure
sections.body: One of the most common tactics scammers use is creating a false sense of urgency. They want you to act quickly before you have time to think critically or verify the message. This pressure is designed to override your natural caution with fear of negative consequences.

interactionData.question: Which of these messages shows the most obvious urgency red flag?

options.text: Your package will be delivered tomorrow between 2-5pm.
options.feedback: This is a normal delivery notification with a reasonable timeframe.

options.text: Your Amazon account password will expire in 7 days. Please update it at your convenience.
options.feedback: While this mentions a deadline, 7 days is a reasonable timeframe that doesn't create extreme urgency.

options.text: URGENT: Your account will be PERMANENTLY DELETED in 1 HOUR if you don't verify now!
options.feedback: Correct! This message uses extreme urgency with an unreasonable 1-hour deadline and threatening permanent consequences to pressure you into immediate action.

options.text: Your monthly statement is now available. Please review it by the end of the month.
options.feedback: This is a routine notification with a reasonable timeframe.

sections.title: Recognizing Urgency Tactics
sections.body: Scammers use specific techniques to create urgency in their messages. Learning to identify these tactics will help you spot scam attempts.

expandableItems.title: Extremely Short Deadlines
expandableItems.content: Legitimate organizations give reasonable timeframes for important actions, usually days or weeks, not minutes or hours. Messages demanding action within minutes or a few hours are almost always scams.

expandableItems.title: Severe Negative Consequences
expandableItems.content: Threats about immediate account closure, legal action, arrest, or other serious consequences for not responding immediately are hallmarks of scams. Legitimate organizations follow established processes that include multiple notifications over time.

expandableItems.title: Countdown Timers & Expiration Notices
expandableItems.content: Including visual countdown timers or emphasizing limited time with phrases like 'final notice' or 'expires in 24 HOURS' creates artificial time pressure. These are designed to force hasty decisions before you can think critically.

sections.title: Poor Grammar and Communication
sections.body: Many scammers operate internationally or use automated translation tools, resulting in messages with grammatical errors, unusual phrasing, or inconsistent formatting. While legitimate organizations occasionally make mistakes, multiple errors should raise suspicion.

dragItems.text: Your account has been temporarily suspended. Please sign in to restore access.
DEAR CUSTOMAR, We need verify you're account information urgent.
The your package is waiting for picking up. You must make delivery payment.
Your monthly statement is ready. Log in to view and manage your account.
wE have Detected SUSPICIOUS activity on youre ACCOUNT

sections.title: Why Grammar Matters
sections.body: Understanding why poor grammar and communication are red flags can help you spot scams more effectively.

expandableItems.title: Multiple Spelling or Grammatical Errors
expandableItems.content: Legitimate companies have professional communications teams that proofread messages to prevent obvious errors. Multiple spelling mistakes, wrong words, or poor grammar often indicate a scam operation without these quality controls.

expandableItems.title: Awkward Phrasing or Unusual Word Choices
expandableItems.content: Strange sentence structures or word choices often indicate that text has been translated from another language or generated by AI. This is common in international scam operations where English isn't the primary language.

expandableItems.title: Inconsistent Capitalization and Formatting
expandableItems.content: Professional communications maintain consistent formatting and style. Messages with RANDOM capitalization, inconsistent spacing, or mixture of fonts and styling are often scams created without professional design standards.

sections.title: Requests for Personal Information
sections.body: Scammers frequently try to collect personal information that can be used for identity theft or to access your accounts. Legitimate organizations generally don't request sensitive information via text message, especially not as an initial contact method.

interactionData.question: Which of these requests would be the most dangerous to respond to?

options.text: Please rate your recent customer service experience from 1-5 stars.
options.feedback: This is a common legitimate request that doesn't ask for any sensitive information.

options.text: To verify your identity, please reply with your Social Security Number and date of birth.
options.feedback: Correct! This requests highly sensitive personal information that could be used for identity theft. Legitimate organizations never ask for complete SSNs via text.

options.text: Click here to see your delivery status and estimated arrival time.
options.feedback: While you should be cautious about clicking links, this doesn't directly request personal information (though the link might lead to a phishing site).

options.text: Reply YES to confirm your appointment for tomorrow at 2:00 PM.
options.feedback: This is asking for a simple confirmation without requesting any sensitive personal information.

sections.title: Types of Sensitive Information Scammers Request
sections.body: Scammers typically target specific types of information they can use to steal your identity or access your accounts.

expandableItems.title: Financial Information
expandableItems.content: Credit card numbers, account numbers, PINs, CVV codes, and online banking passwords are prime targets. Legitimate organizations never ask for complete financial details via text message.

expandableItems.title: Identity Information
expandableItems.content: Social Security Numbers, dates of birth, mother's maiden name, and full addresses can be used to steal your identity. Government agencies and financial institutions already have this information and won't ask for it via text.

expandableItems.title: Login Credentials
expandableItems.content: Usernames, passwords, and verification codes for any account are valuable to scammers. No legitimate service will ever ask for your password or authentication code via text message. These are strictly for your use only.

expandableItems.title: Medical Information
expandableItems.content: Health insurance numbers, medical record numbers, and healthcare portal passwords can be used for medical identity theft. Healthcare providers communicate sensitive information through secure patient portals, not via standard text messages.

sections.title: Suspicious Links and URLs
sections.body: Most text scams include links to fake websites designed to steal information or install malware. These links often have subtle differences from legitimate URLs or use shortened links to hide their true destination.

interactionData.question: Which of these URLs is most likely legitimate?

options.text: https://bank0famerica-secure.com/login
options.feedback: This is suspicious - note the '0' (zero) instead of 'o' in 'bank0famerica' and the addition of '-secure' to make it seem trustworthy. Bank of America's actual domain is bankofamerica.com.

options.text: https://amzn-delivery-notify.info/track
options.feedback: This is suspicious - Amazon doesn't use 'amzn-delivery-notify.info' domain. Their legitimate domains include amazon.com and authorized variants like smile.amazon.com.

options.text: https://bit.ly/3xLr8Kp
options.feedback: Shortened URLs like this hide their true destination, making them risky. You can't tell where this link actually leads without clicking it.

options.text: https://chase.com/account/login
options.feedback: Correct! This uses the legitimate main domain for Chase Bank (chase.com) with a logical path structure. Always verify you're on the official domain before entering any information.

sections.title: How to Safely Inspect Links
sections.body: Before clicking any link in a text message, you should inspect it carefully. Here are techniques to evaluate link safety without clicking.

expandableItems.title: Check the Main Domain Name
expandableItems.content: Look for the domain name (what comes before .com, .org, etc. and after www. or http://). Legitimate companies use their official, simple domains. For example, Bank of America uses 'bankofamerica.com', not variations like 'bank-of-america.com' or 'bankofamerica-secure.com'.

expandableItems.title: Look for Typos and Substitutions
expandableItems.content: Check for subtle misspellings or character substitutions (like using a zero '0' instead of the letter 'o', or the number '1' instead of the letter 'l'). These are common tactics to create domains that look legitimate at a glance.

expandableItems.title: Hover Without Clicking (on computers)
expandableItems.content: On computers, hovering your mouse over a link without clicking will show the destination URL in the browser's status bar or in a tooltip. On mobile, pressing and holding a link (without releasing) often shows a preview of where it leads.

expandableItems.title: Search for the Company Directly
expandableItems.content: Instead of clicking any link, open your browser and search for the company directly. Click on the official result and navigate to the relevant section. This way, you know you're on the legitimate website.

sections.title: Unexpected or Out-of-Context Messages
sections.body: Scammers often send messages that appear to be from companies you don't do business with or about activities you haven't engaged in. Always be suspicious of unexpected messages, especially those claiming to be from organizations you don't recognize or services you don't use.

dragItems.text: Your Netflix payment of $49.99 has been processed, but you don't have a Netflix account
Your recent Amazon order #A12345 has shipped, and you did recently order from Amazon
Your Chase credit card shows a $500 purchase at Best Buy, and you do shop at Best Buy
You've won a $1,000 Walmart gift card, but you never entered a contest
Reminder about your doctor's appointment tomorrow, which you scheduled last week
AT&T: You're eligible for a $75 refund due to overcharging, but you don't use AT&T

sections.title: Context Clues for Identifying Scams
sections.body: Understanding why unexpected messages are suspicious can help you better protect yourself.

expandableItems.title: Messages from Organizations You Don't Use
expandableItems.content: If you don't have an account with a company or use their services, be extremely suspicious of any message claiming to be from them. Legitimate businesses only contact existing customers.

expandableItems.title: Notifications About Unknown Activities
expandableItems.content: Messages about orders, shipments, subscriptions, or payments you don't recognize are major red flags. Scammers hope you'll panic about an unknown charge or delivery and react without thinking.

expandableItems.title: Unsolicited Offers and Prizes
expandableItems.content: Unexpected offers, prizes, or refunds you didn't request are almost always scams. Legitimate offers are typically tied to your known activities or accounts, and companies don't randomly give away large prizes via text message.

expandableItems.title: How to Verify Suspicious Messages
expandableItems.content: If you're unsure about a message from a company you do business with, never use the contact information provided in the message. Instead, look up the company's official contact information separately and reach out directly to verify if the message is legitimate.

sections.title: Spotting Multiple Red Flags
sections.body: The most dangerous scam messages often contain multiple red flags. Learning to identify combinations of warning signs will make you more scam-resistant.

interactionData.question: Which message shows the MOST red flags?

options.text: Your package is scheduled for delivery tomorrow between 2-4pm. No action required.
options.feedback: This message doesn't show red flags - it provides information without requesting action, doesn't create urgency, and doesn't include suspicious links.

options.text: URGENT: Your Bank Account been FROZEN due to suspicious activites! Verify you're identity now: http://bank0famerica-secure.com/verify or call 888-555-1234 in 2 HOURS to avoid permanent closure!
options.feedback: Correct! This contains MULTIPLE red flags: urgency ('URGENT'), short deadline (2 hours), severe consequences (account closure), poor grammar ('activites', 'you're' instead of 'your'), suspicious link (misspelled domain with 'bank0famerica'), and a request for identity verification.

options.text: Amazon order #A12345 has been delivered. Signature was provided by: SMITH
options.feedback: This message doesn't show clear red flags - it's providing delivery confirmation information without requesting action.

options.text: Your credit card payment is due in 3 days. Please log in to your account to make a payment.
options.feedback: This message shows few red flags - the timeframe is reasonable (3 days), and it directs you to log in to your account rather than clicking a provided link.

quiz.question: Which of the following is a common red flag indicating a text message might be a scam?

options.text: The message addresses you by your correct full name
options.feedback: Legitimate messages often use your name. Scams frequently use generic greetings or incorrect names.

options.text: The message contains multiple spelling and grammatical errors
options.feedback: Correct! Multiple spelling and grammatical errors are a strong indicator of a scam. Legitimate organizations typically have professional communications that are carefully proofread.

options.text: The message comes from a number saved in your contacts
options.feedback: While scammers can spoof numbers, messages from saved contacts are generally less likely to be scams.

options.text: The message references a recent legitimate purchase you made
options.feedback: Messages relating to actual activities you've engaged in are more likely to be legitimate.

quiz.question: How do scammers typically use urgency in their messages?

options.text: They provide reasonable timeframes for you to respond at your convenience
options.feedback: Scammers typically use unreasonable, short timeframes, not reasonable ones.

options.text: They create artificial time pressure to force hasty decisions
options.feedback: Correct! Scammers want you to act quickly before you have time to think critically or verify the message.

options.text: They suggest you might want to take action sometime in the next few weeks
options.feedback: Scammers rarely give extended timeframes as this allows too much time for verification.

options.text: They only mention deadlines for optional promotional offers
options.feedback: Scammers typically use deadlines for critical account issues or legal matters, not just promotional offers.

quiz.question: What is concerning about a text message that includes a shortened URL (like bit.ly or tinyurl)?

options.text: Shortened URLs always lead to malware
options.feedback: While shortened URLs can be used maliciously, they're also used legitimately in many contexts.

options.text: Shortened URLs are only used by foreign scammers
options.feedback: URL shorteners are used globally by both legitimate services and scammers.

options.text: The true destination of the link is hidden from view
options.feedback: Correct! Shortened URLs hide the actual destination, making it impossible to verify if it's legitimate before clicking.

options.text: Shortened URLs expire quickly
options.feedback: Most shortened URLs don't have short expiration times.

quiz.question: Which of these requests in a text message is the strongest indicator of a scam?

options.text: Asking you to rate your customer service experience
options.feedback: Service ratings are commonly requested by legitimate businesses.

options.text: Asking you to reply with your account password to verify your identity
options.feedback: Correct! No legitimate service will ever ask for your password via text message. This is a definite scam indicator.

options.text: Asking you to confirm receipt of a delivery
options.feedback: Delivery confirmations are standard practice for many shipping companies.

options.text: Asking you to download their official mobile app from an app store
options.feedback: Directing users to download official apps from legitimate app stores is common practice.

quiz.question: If you receive a text about your Amazon order being delayed, but you haven't ordered anything from Amazon recently, what is this an example of?

options.text: A suspicious link red flag
options.feedback: While the message might contain a suspicious link, this isn't the primary red flag described.

options.text: An out-of-context or unexpected message red flag
options.feedback: Correct! Messages about activities you haven't engaged in (like orders you didn't place) are a key red flag of scams.

options.text: A poor grammar and communication red flag
options.feedback: The scenario doesn't mention grammar issues, though they might also be present.

options.text: An urgency and time pressure red flag
options.feedback: The scenario doesn't specifically mention urgency tactics, though they might be present as well.

quiz.question: What's the best approach when analyzing a suspicious text message?

options.text: Focus on only one red flag to determine if it's a scam
options.feedback: Looking for just one red flag might miss other warning signs. Scam messages often contain multiple indicators.

options.text: Look for a combination of multiple red flags
options.feedback: Correct! The most effective approach is to look for multiple red flags together, as sophisticated scams often combine several deceptive tactics.

options.text: Only be suspicious if the message is from an unknown number
options.feedback: Scammers can spoof familiar numbers or hack accounts, so even messages from known numbers can be scams.

options.text: Assume all text messages requesting any action are scams
options.feedback: While caution is good, legitimate organizations do send action requests via text. The key is identifying suspicious elements.
